The chart presents the different purposes for which students at a certain university use their phones for reading. According to the chart, the percentages indicate their preferences. The most popular purpose is learning knowledge, chosen by 59.5% of respondents. This is followed by killing time at 21.3%, and getting information comes next at 17.0%. The “other” category has the lowest percentage at 2.2%.

The above percentages reflect residents’ tendency to exercise alone. We can attribute this phenomenon to the following aspects. In begin with, compared to exercising with others, exercising alone offers greater flexibility and freedom, leading residents to prefer exercising alone. What’s more,with the rapid development of science and technology, mobile phones are accessible, and cell-phone reading enjoys great popularity among university students.there are now more tools available to help us create personalized exercise plans, making solo workouts more efficient. Additionally, another significant portion of people choose to exercise with friends, which may be because having company allows for mutual supervision without the chaos that can come with group exercises.

To sum up, we can predict that this trend will continue in the future, because it conforms to the characteristics of modem university students and our times.（Based on the above reasons, we can draw the conclusion that an increasing number of people are willing to exercise alone and the trend may continue in the future. Certainly, no matter which way of exercise you choose, it’s the action that counts・）

Based on the First Chart

Interpretation:

The pie chart illustrates the main purposes for which students at a certain university use their mobile phones for reading. According to the data, 59.5% of students primarily use their phones to learn new knowledge, making it the most common reason. Another 21.3% use their phones to pass time, 17.0% to obtain information, and 2.2% for other reasons.

Commentary:

  1. Educational Convenience: The majority (59.5%) of students use their phones for educational purposes, likely due to the convenience and accessibility of digital learning materials. Smartphones allow students to access a wide range of educational resources anytime and anywhere, enhancing their learning experience.
  2. Leisure Activities: A significant portion (21.3%) of students use their phones to pass time, indicating that smartphones serve as a primary source of entertainment. This may be due to the availability of various apps and media that provide engaging content, making it easier for students to relax and unwind.
  3. Information Access: The 17.0% of students who use their phones to obtain information highlight the role of smartphones as tools for quick and easy access to news and updates. This reflects the growing importance of staying informed in today’s fast-paced world.

Based on the Second Chart

Interpretation:

The bar chart shows the preferences of residents in a certain city regarding their methods of physical exercise. According to the data, the most popular method is exercising alone, chosen by 54.30% of respondents. Exercising with friends follows closely at 47.70%, while exercising with family members is selected by 23.90%. Participating in group activities is the least preferred method, chosen by only 15.80%.

Commentary:

  1. Flexibility and Personalization: The majority (54.30%) of residents prefer to exercise alone, likely because it offers greater flexibility and allows them to tailor their workouts to their personal schedules and preferences. This flexibility is particularly important for those with busy lifestyles.
  2. Social Interaction: A significant portion (47.70%) of residents choose to exercise with friends, suggesting that social interaction and mutual encouragement play a crucial role in maintaining motivation and enjoyment during exercise.
  3. Family Bonding: The 23.90% of residents who exercise with family members indicate that family activities can also be a motivating factor. Engaging in physical activities together can strengthen family bonds and promote a healthy lifestyle within the household.

The bar chart presents the comparison between the employment status of undergraduate graduates from a certain university in 2013 and 2018（from 2013 to 2018）. (It shows three categories: employment, further education, and entrepreneurship.) In 2013, the majority of graduates chose to enter the job market directly, accounting for 68.1%. In contrast, only 26.3% opted for further education, while a mere 1.3% decided to start their own businesses. By 2018, however, the situation had changed noticeably. The proportion of graduates who went straight into employment dropped to 60.7%, whereas those pursuing higher education increased significantly to 34.0%. Interestingly, the number of graduates choosing to embark on entrepreneurial ventures also rose slightly to 2.6%.

We can attribute this phenomenon to the following aspects. To begin with,the drop/rise in the proportion of employment appears probably because college students are confronted with great job hunting pressure.

The bar chart illustrates the changes in China’s express delivery volume from 2018 to 2020, comparing the total volume and rural volume separately. Over the three-year period, the total express delivery volume saw a significant increase, rising from 51 billion pieces in 2018 to 83 billion pieces in 2020. Similarly, the rural express delivery volume also experienced growth, increasing from 12 billion pieces in 2018 to 30 billion pieces in 2020.

These trends suggest a growing reliance on e-commerce and online shopping across China, particularly in rural areas. The expansion of logistics infrastructure and improved accessibility to online services likely contributed to this rise. Moreover, the increasing popularity of online platforms may have encouraged more people to purchase goods remotely, further driving up the demand for express delivery services.

In summary, the chart demonstrates a clear upward trajectory in both total and rural express delivery volumes in China from 2018 to 2020, reflecting broader shifts towards digital commerce and enhanced connectivity within the country.

The bar chart shows the changes in the Air Quality Index (AQI) in four big Chinese cities—Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen—from 2010 to 2020. This chart helps us understand how the air quality has changed in these cities over the years.

In Beijing, the AQI went down a lot, from 120 in 2010 to 80 in 2020. This big drop means the air quality got much better, probably because of strong environmental rules and actions taken by the government. Shanghai also saw a similar change, with its AQI going down from 110 to 75, showing that the city is working hard to reduce pollution.On the other hand, Guangzhou’s AQI stayed almost the same, between 90 and 100. This means the air quality in Guangzhou didn’t change much, even though the city is trying to keep it steady. In Shenzhen, the AQI went up a little, from 70 to 85. This small increase is worrying and shows that the air quality is getting worse, which needs attention.

Overall, the chart tells us that Beijing and Shanghai have done a good job in improving air quality, thanks to their strong environmental policies. However, Guangzhou’s air quality didn’t change much, and Shenzhen’s got worse. These results show that different cities need different plans to deal with pollution and keep the environment clean.

Following closely, 26.80% of consumers focused on service(acquiring information account for around 20%), while 23.80% considered price. The special features and other factors accounted for 8.40% and 4.70% respectively.

The high percentage for special features in chart,at 36.30%,indicates that this factor is the primary concern for most consumers when choosing a restaurant. there are several reasons to explain the phenomenon. First of all, the rising income levels greatly improved consumers’ choose of restaurant. What’s more,the widespread adoption of the internet and mobile devices has made information more accessible. Therefore,people could more liking to choose that they not see and 体验过的 thing. Therefore ,people are more likely to choose experiences or option that they have not seen or experienced before.

To sum up,with the development of society, people’s choices have become more diverse, and they are paying more attention to spiritual pursuits. It is expected that this trend will also apply to other areas.
